text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Revised IRM to reflect new organizational titles resulting from the Appeals 2012 Alignment Project.

This supersedes IRM 4.48.2 dated December 14, 2010, and incorporates Interim Guidance, Mandatory Use of the Specialist Referral System (SRS) for Art Appraisal Services (AAS), Control No. AP-08-0612-03.
Criminal Investigation (CI), Large Business & International (LB&I), Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE), Wage & Investment (W&I), Chief Counsel
Table of
4.48.2.1 Art Appraisal Services Overview
for Cases Involving Works of Art
) Art Appraisal Services (AAS): (cid:
) Provides advice and assistance to the Service, other Government agencies, and taxpayers on valuation questions arising in connection personal property and works of art, (cid:
) Assists the Office of Chief Counsel and Department of Justice (DOJ) in appraisal reviews for trial or pretrial settlement in cases involving issues, and (cid:
) Manages the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel. (

) The Commissioner maintains an Art Advisory Panel of nationally prominent museum directors, curators, scholars, art dealers, auction representatives, appraisers to systematically aid the Service in the review of cases involving taxpayer valuations on art objects, principally American and European paintings and sculpture. (
) AAS provides the staff support and coordination of the Panel’s functions. (

) The Panel members, after reviewing photographs or color transparencies, along with relevant documentation provided by the taxpayers and research the staff appraisers, make recommendations on the acceptability of the claimed values. If unacceptable, the Panelists make alternate value recom- mendations. Such recommendations are advisory only; however, after by AAS, these recommendations become the position of the Service. (

) Reconsideration of Value Determinations. If agreement cannot be with the taxpayer, further assistance may be requested of AAS and the The taxpayer may request reconsideration of an adjusted claimed value they provide additional evidence such as comparable sales data or other relevant facts to support their fair market value opinion. The taxpayer’s must respond specifically to the report issued by AAS. (

) Further Assistance. The appraisers will provide assistance to the Divisions, Appeals and Chief Counsel. Upon request, the designated may participate in taxpayer conferences, may prepare a detailed expert for use in Tax Court trials, and may testify as an expert witness in support the report or may assist in procuring outside experts and/or Panelists. (
) IRS employees must refer cases to AAS that involve a taxpayer’s appraisal a single work of art with a claimed value of $

or more, including paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures, antiques, ceramics, decorative arts, textiles, carpets, silver, rare manuscripts, antiquities, ethnographic art, col- lectibles, classic automobiles, and historical memorabilia. Subject to the discretion of AAS, the taxpayer’s appraisal may also be submitted for addi- tional review by the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel. (
) AAS appraisers also provide valuation assistance on art work valued at $
(in special cases), as well as works of art and other collectibles not referred to the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel. (
) Requesters may contact the AAS appraisers by telephone to informally a valuation to determine the type of assistance required and whether a written request is needed.

(10-01-2012) Criteria for Requesting Art Appraisal Services Assistance
) When a formal request is appropriate, it must be written and forwarded to via the Specialist Referral System, https://srs.web.irs.gov. Appraisal Services (
) For more information, see: Procedures (cid:

, Art Valuation Requests Overview, (cid:

, Art Valuation Request Requirements, and (cid:
) Appeals AAS referrals website, http://appeals.web.irs.gov/art/ art_referrals.htm.. (
) Form
, Art Valuation is a feedback loop form that AAS partially completes and includes with its closing memorandum and report, and the
Procedures referring office completes and returns to AAS upon disposition of the case. Note: The referring employee’s manager is responsible for ensuring that a copy of the completed Form
is returned to AAS immediately upon disposition the case. a. The AAS appraiser completes Section I of Form
and attaches it to the AAS closing memorandum and report. b. The referring office completes Section II of Form
and mails a copy the updated Form
to: Internal Revenue Service/Appeals Attn: Director, AAS (AP:SO:ART)
Constitution Ave, Suite
Washington, DC
Note: Keep the updated original Form
, along with the AAS closing dum and report , in the case workpaper file, after indexing it on Examination Workpapers Form
or Estate and Gift Tax Exam planning documents and/or lead sheets and workpapers. (
) To further enhance the valuation assistance provided by AAS, requesters are encouraged to include comments and supporting documentation that would beneficial to the viability of this program. (
) Also see IRM
, Receiving Office’s Closing Procedures, for additional information.
